medicad.description:
• Most recent waiver amendment (without SUD features) approved on 12/22/2017; demonstration effective 12/30/2015 through 12/31/2020
  • Waiver amendment with SUD features approved on 8/13/2015

• Delivery system reform demonstration that authorizes, among other features:
    • SUD initiative called Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS), which aligns with July 2015 SMD letter; state provides a full continuum of SUD benefits and has obtained a waiver of the IMD exclusion
      • DMC-ODS provides both State Plan benefits and benefits newly authorized under the demonstration
      • Counties have the option of participating in DMC-ODS
      • The full range of DMC-ODS benefits (see below) are available only to Medicaid enrollees residing in a participating county; the more limited State Plan SUD benefit package is available in nonparticipating counties
    • Public Hospital Redesign & Incentives in Medi-Cal (PRIME), a follow-up to the state’s DSRIP initiative authorized under an earlier version of the demonstration
      • Includes projects implemented through designated public hospital systems and district/municipal public hospitals that target primary care/BH integration
    • Whole Person Care (WPC) pilots
      • Designed to coordinate physical health, BH and social services through collaboration among county agencies, health plans and providers with a focus on vulnerable populations
      • May be led by a city; a county; both a city and county; a health or hospital authority; or a consortium of cities, counties and/or health or hospital authorities
      • Provide access to interventions that would not otherwise be covered by Medicaid (e.g., tenancy-based care management services, county housing pools to support medically necessary housing services)
      • May select individuals with SUDs or MH disorders as a target population
medicad.category_name: Waiver Design Summary and Key SUD-Related Waiver Features

    • Intensive in-home services pilot: Covers intensive in-home services for up to 18,650 enrollees ages 3–21 who meet the state’s health home eligibility criteria and have significant BH needs

CMS rejected Wisconsin’s request to require as a condition of eligibility that individuals complete an annual drug use screening. Wisconsin requested that individuals with a positive screening who did not indicate a willingness to enter SUD treatment be required to complete a drug test, and individuals with a positive drug test be required to complete SUD treatment. In addition, Wisconsin requested that failure to complete drug screening, a drug test, or SUD treatment result in disenrollment, and individuals be required to consent to drug treatment before re-enrolling. Individuals who indicated a willingness to obtain SUD treatment would not have been required to complete drug screening as a condition of eligibility.

Wisconsin is in the midst of transitioning to managed care a subset of enrollees eligible for Medicaid on the basis of receiving SSI.
